statement.p: Explain why the vectors \left[\begin{array}{r} 4 \\ -3 \\ -4 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ 0 \\ 2 \\ 0 \\ -2 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} -4 \\ 3 \\ -2 \\ 1 \\ 5 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} -4 \\ 3 \\ 8 \\ 1 \\ -5 \end{array}\right] , \text{ and } \left[\begin{array}{r} 8 \\ -6 \\ -8 \\ -2 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] are or are not a basis of \mathbb{R}^5

answer.p: The vectors \left[\begin{array}{r} 4 \\ -3 \\ -4 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ 0 \\ 2 \\ 0 \\ -2 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} -4 \\ 3 \\ -2 \\ 1 \\ 5 \end{array}\right] , \left[\begin{array}{r} -4 \\ 3 \\ 8 \\ 1 \\ -5 \end{array}\right] , \text{ and } \left[\begin{array}{r} 8 \\ -6 \\ -8 \\ -2 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] are not a basis of \mathbb{R}^5.
